elected 01  1292009 public nuisance task force   purposeestablishment a public nuisance task force is hereby established the purpose of and primary goal of the task force is to work with property owners to establish a plan to abate identified nuisances in a timely manner collaborative effort of task force members and the property owners where there is ineffective cooperation from a property owners the task force may review appropriate legal remedies to abate the nuisance  part 2003   members the members of the public nuisance task force shall consist of the following members 1 the police chief or hisher designee 2 the fire chief or hisher designee  3 the director of the planning department or hisher designee  4 the city solicitor or hisher designee  5 the city council person from the ward in which the subject property is located  6 a city council person atlarge chosen by the mayor  7 and other persons or agencies deemed necessary by the task force members  8 when deemed appropriate the attorney general may designate a representative to assist the task force with continuing chronic nuisances  part 2003   mission the task force shall investigate problem properties by reviewing police reports  building housing and zoning code violations  fire safety code violations  and complaints of properties with potentially hazardous conditions the primary focus of the task force shall be on properties that present ongoing chronic code violations and numerous calls for police fire or emergency service  part 2003   procedures members of the task force shall identify properties that present chronic public nuisance issues for the city and after adequate review and investigation notice shall be sent to the property owners to abate the identified nuisances or provide the task force with a comprehensive plan for abatement within ten 10 days a request will be made to the property owners to meet with the task force to discuss the public nuisances maintained on the subject property and develop an abatement plan the plan must resolve all nuisance related issues within ninety 90 days following the task forces approval of the plan upon request the task force shall provide general but limited guidance during the abatement process however the property owners shall remain solely responsible for knowing all laws codes and regulations applicable to the maintenance of the property  part 2003   chair and meeting the director of planning department shall serve as chair of the public nuisance task force the task force shall meet regularly as necessary to consider and review subject properties and to meet with notified property owners regarding the abatement of public nuisance  part 2003 henderson home   board of commissioners a membership the board of commissioners of henderson home shall consist of five members who shall be residents of the city they shall be elected by council annually and shall serve without compensation whenever a vacancy occurs on the board council at its next meeting shall proceed to fill such vacancy for the remainder of the unexpired term b officers the officers of the board shall consist of a chairman a secretary and a treasurer they shall be annually elected by the commissioners and shall hold their respective offices for one year or until their successors are chosen and qualified in their stead c records the board shall keep a record of its proceedings and a full and accurate account of all moneys which may come into its hands and under its management from the bequest of william h henderson or from any other source including the uses and applications thereof in a suitable book or books kept for such purposes which shall at all reasonable times be kept open for public inspection at the home d annual report to council at each annual meeting of council in the month of january the board shall make a written report of the general state of the home consisting of a statement of the number of inmates and beneficiaries at the beginning of the year the number admitted deceased left or discharged and the number remaining together with a written report of the treasurer with an account of the receipts and expenditures of the board e meetings generally a meeting of the board shall be held at least once in each month at a time fixed by the board special meetings shall be called by the secretary at any time upon the request of the chairman or upon the request of any two commissioners in each instance the purpose and object of such special meeting shall be set forth in the notice f annual meeting the annual meeting of the board shall be held on the last secular day of december g quorum three members of the board present shall constitute a quorum h duties of chairman chairman pro tem the chairman shall preside at all meetings if present in his absence a chairman pro tempore shall be elected i duties of secretary the secretary shall keep a correct record of the proceedings of each meeting file and preserve all documents belonging to the board cause notice of all meetings to be given to each commissioner and generally perform such other duties appertaining to his or her office as the board may from time to time require j secretary pro tem in case of the secretarys absence or inability to act the board shall elect a secretary pro tempore who shall perform the duties of that office accordingly 01   officers and servants the board of commissioners shall appoint such officers and servants as are necessary for the operation and care of the home and shall fix their compensation the board shall have the right to remove any officer or servant whenever it deems such action desirable 02   duties of treasurer a under the control and direction of the board of commissioners the treasurer shall receive all moneys which may come to the board in the transaction of its business and shall deposit the same in the name of the board in such depositary or depositaries as it directs the treasurer shall make payments when directed by the board and only upon warrants signed by the chairman and the secretary the treasurer shall keep a record of all moneys which come into his or her possession and of all disbursements therefrom b at the annual meeting and as often as called upon to do so the treasurer shall render to the board an account in detail of all receipts and disbursements and a statement of the property under its management the treasurer shall when called upon give such other information in regard to the property in his or her possession as may be requested of him or her by the board and his or her books shall at all times be open to the boards inspection c the treasurer shall perform such other duties as usually appertain to the office of treasurer 03   treasurer pro tem in case of the treasurers absence or inability to act the board of commissioners shall elect a treasurer pro tempore who shall perform the duties of that office accordingly 04   record of applicants the board of commissioners shall keep a record in which shall be entered the names of all applicants their respective ages places of birth and residences by whom recommended the dates of application the decisions of the board in respect thereto and all other facts the board may deem advisable 05   acquisition of real estate the board of commissioners shall purchase or erect in the city a suitable estate or building which shall be used and maintained as a home for aged men of good moral character who are unable to support themselves and which shall be called the henderson home for aged men 06   management of homecontracts the board of commissioners shall manage the home in accordance with the provisions contained in the will of william h henderson deceased and shall have full authority and power to enter into and execute such contracts in relation thereto as it may deem expedient 07   admission and expulsion of applicants the board of commissions shall have the right to exercise its discretion as to the admissibility of any applicant but no applicant shall be admitted unless he has been a resident of the city for at least five consecutive years the board shall have the right to dismiss and expel from the home any inmate who violates any of the rules or whose presence in its judgment is prejudicial to the best interests of the home or who for any reason is deemed not to be a proper recipient of the benefits of the bequest 08   inspectionvisiting rights the home shall always be open to the commissioners and it shall be open at all reasonable times to public inspection the board of commissioners shall designate in each week at least one afternoon during which inmates may receive visitors at such hours and under such conditions as the board may establish 09   rules and regulations the board of commissioners may make such additional rules and regulations for its own guidance and for the government of its officers and servants for the care of the inmates and the proper conduct of the home as it may deem advisable provided the same do not conflict with the provisions of the will of william h henderson deceased 10 purchasing agent   designation pursuant to of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws the city manager is designated as purchasing officer the purchasing agent for the city of newport for purposes of exercising the powers and duties as set forth in of title 45 of the rhode island general laws and title 2 of the codified ordinances of the city of newport  part 1999 purchasing systemcompetitive bidding   amounts less than one thousand dollars any purchase of or contract for supplies materials or equipment up to one thousand dollars $100000 may be made without competitive bidding by the purchasing agent with the approval of the city manager  part 2002   amounts from one thousand dollars to five thousand dollars any purchase of or contract for supplies materials or equipment over one thousand dollars $100000 but not over five thousand dollars $500000 shall be made by the purchasing agent with the approval of the city manager only after informal quotations have been received  part 2002  1292009   amounts of more than five thousand dollars any purchase of or contract for supplies materials or equipment of between five thousand dollars $500000 and ten thousand dollars $1000000 shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after one public advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the area by an award committee consisting of the purchasing agent a requesting department representative and a disinterested city employee selected by the city manager the award committee shall have power to award or reject all bids and advertise for new bids within their threshold dollar limit alterations in any contract entered into may be made within the threshold dollar limit when authorized by the award committee on a written recommendation from the city manager any purchase of or contract for supplies materials or equipment of more than ten thousand dollars $1000000 shall be awarded by the city council however any purchase of or contract for proprietary articles or replacement parts or equipment may be made from the manufacturer or his authorized agent without public advertisement or competitive bidding upon the approval of the city manager  part 1990  prior code  22222c  1292009   proposals proposals must be in sealed envelopes addressed to the purchasing division city hall newport rhode island 028 and plainly marked on the lower left hand corner bid for insert item being bid for  22d   bidders responsibility it is the bidders responsibility to see that his bid is delivered within the time and at the place prescribed bids received prior to the time of opening will be securely kept unopened bids may be withdrawn on written request on the letterhead of the bidder and signed by the person signing the bid which must be received prior to the time fixed for opening bids may be modified in the same manner no bid or modification thereof received after the time set for opening will be considered even if it is determined by the city that such nonarrival before the time set for opening was due solely to delay in the mails for which the bidder is not responsible 22e   taxes federal excise taxes andor rhode island use taxes are not to be included in the quotation exemption certificates will be executed by the city if furnished by the contractor when submitting his invoice 22g   discounts any cash discount offered shall be for payment within a period of not less than fifteen 15 days all prices quoted shall be net and delivered fob newport rhode island to the purchasing division all invoices shall be rendered in duplicate to the purchasing division 22h   bonds each bid must be accompanied by an acceptable bid bond certified check cashiers check or cash in an amount set by the purchasing agent deposits of unsuccessful bidders will be returned without interest as promptly as possible after the award is made the deposit of the successful bidder will be retained as a performance bond or until a substitute performance bond in the same amount is furnished to guarantee that all conditions and specifications will be met 22i   bid papers one set of bid papers is furnished to bidders which must be returned if a bid is rendered all figures must be written in ink if not typewritten 22j   citys rights the right is reserved as the interest of the city may require to reject any or all bids to waive any technical defect or informality in bids received and to accept or reject any bid or portion thereof 22k   failure of successful bidder to complete contract if the bidder to whom the contract is awarded fails to complete the contract in a timely and workmanlike manner the city may remove the contractor from the job pursuant to the terms of the contract the city may then offer the remaining work to the next lowest responsible bidder from that list established for the bids received for the specific job 22l   exceptions any bidder taking exception to or questioning any of the provisions procedures conditions or specifications herein stated should make such exception known to the city in writing not less than five days before the bid opening any change or interpretation made as a result thereof will be published in an addendum and mailed to all prospective bidders should a bidder still not be satisfied he may in his bid set out and stipulate his exception with enough explanation to be understood by the city and within the stipulation the increase or decrease in his bid price because of the exception shall be stated the city may at its discretion accept or reject any or al exceptions 22f use of competitive negotiation in award of contracts   purpose the ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted pursuant to of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws and the charter of the city of newport to provide for the conduct of competitive negotiation in the award of contracts by the city  part 1999   contract awardstatutory processdetermination a notwithstanding any otherwise applicable provisions of the codified ordinances of the city of newport with regard to the award of contracts a contract may be awarded by the city process of competitive negotiations as outlined in of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws and this chapter if the purchasing agent determines in writing that the use of competitive sealed bids for the award of the contract by the city as set forth in of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws is not practicable in making a determination as to the practicability of competitive sealed bidding for purposes of these regulations the purchasing agent shall consider all factors he or she deems relevant to the particular procurement including the following 1 whether specifications can be prepared that permit award on the basis of either the lowest qualified bid price or the lowest qualified evaluated bid price  2 whether the available sources the time and place of performance and other relevant circumstances are appropriate for the use of competitive sealed bidding  3 whether competition as to matters of design construction approach materials and methodology performance guarantees repair and replacement obligations relative strength of financial backing and similar matters affecting the overall value of the resulting contract as well as competition as to price will best serve the interests of the city  4 whether the contract is expected to involve combined multiple complex or diverse services or elements of performance that lend themselves to an evaluation of offers on a basis other than lowest qualified bid price or lowest qualified evaluated bid price  5 whether optional offers are desired and encouraged  6 whether judgment is required in evaluating competing proposals and it is in the best interest of the city to require a balancing of price quality experience and other factors and 7 whether clarification development and negotiation of the terms and conditions of the contract are necessary or desirable to achieve the citys goals in the transaction b if determination that the use of competitive sealed bidding is not practicable has been made then the procedures of of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws and this chapter shall be followed notwithstanding any otherwise applicable provisions of the codified ordinances of the city of newport  part 1999   competitive negotiation processprocedures in undertaking a competitive negotiation process for the award of a contract pursuant to this chapter the purchasing agent shall comply with the following procedures a a request for proposals shall be developed which shall indicate the relative importance of price and other evaluation factors which may include to the extent appropriate without limitation previous experience on similar projects previous similar projects with the city financial status and adequacy of financial guarantees of performance technical feasibility of proposal degree and types of contractual risk assumed guarantees of performance to be provided ability to meet its construction andor performance guarantees and commitment to equal opportunity and may include other appropriate items including without limitation detailed performance or design specifications as appropriate  environmental standards which must be conformed with a description of other services that may be required  and any other information deemed appropriate by the purchasing agent b the request for proposals shall also contain a description of the evaluation and selection procedures which shall be followed in awarding the contract including procedures which govern written or oral discussions with proposers the proposal clarification process concurrent or sequential negotiations discontinuance and resumption of negotiations and rights reserved to the city c adequate public notice of the request for proposals shall be given in the manner provided in 3 of the rhode island general laws d award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to the city taking into consideration price and nonprice evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals e prior to issuance of the request for proposals and pursuant to of of title 45 of the rhode island general laws a request for qualifications may be issued in order to develop a short list of prequalified companies such request for qualifications shall indicate the criteria including the relative importance of the criteria and any minimum qualifications criteria and process for evaluation of the submissions received and the maximum number of companies that would be included on the short list the prequalifications criteria may include financial condition management and organization approach relevant project experience and capabilities project approach past performance and other criteria as may be set forth in the request for qualifications if this paragraph e request for qualifications process is utilized distribution of the request for proposals shall be limited to the short list of prequalified companies developed pursuant to the request qualifications and adequate public notice of the request for qualifications shall be given in the manner provided in c of the rhode island general laws  part 1999  surplus property   procedure for disposition of surplus property all real and personal property of the city which is declared surplus after a circulation of all departments as to its usefulness and which is to be disposed of shall be sold at pubic auction after suitable public notice with a fair market value set as a minimum price and such property shall be sold to the highest bidder who complies with the conditions of the sale 09   waiver of procedure the provisions of be waived by a vote of five members of council when such waiver is in the best interest of the city and for the common good a statement by council shall set forth the basis of the best interest of the city and the common good 10   use of proceeds of sale of property the proceeds received from the sale of surplus property as provided in shall be set aside in a fund to be used only for capital expenditures to be appropriated by council the proceeds of the sale of any water department surplus property shall be set aside in 1991   1991   1991   1990   1990   1990   1989   1989   1989  prior code  20801  2252009   2172010   4112012   2262014   2262014   4232014   2112015   8232017   3142018   6122019 title 3  personnel personnel system generally   definitions as used in chapters 304  allocation means the placing of a position in its proper class based upon duties performed and authority and responsibilities exercised applicant means an individual who has completed and submitted an application for employment with the city appointment means the act of the appointing authority in selecting and certifying in writing the person whom he deems best qualified for the position which is to be filled in accordance with the provisions of chapters 304 assembled examination means an examination for which applicants are required to appear at a special place for the purpose of taking a test break in service means any separation from the classified service of one scheduled workday or more whether by resignation layoff dismissal disability retirement or absence without leave of one workweek or more when the employee is subsequently reemployed an authorized leave without pay shall not be considered as constituting a break in service callout time means authorized time worked by any employee who after departing from his shift receives orders to return to work for emergency service candidate means an applicant or employee who is under consideration for a position certification means endorsement as meeting required minimum standards for a vacant position class means a group of positions which are sufficiently alike in general duties and responsibilities to warrant the use of the same title specification and pay range class specification means a written description of a class consisting of a class title a general statement of the level of work and of the distinguishing features of work some examples of duties and the desirable qualifications for the class class title means the official title of the class as specified in the class specifications the term applies to all positions allocated to the class and shall be used in all personnel and administrative processes except that other titles may be used for purposes of internal administration and in any connection not involving the official personnel or payroll processes classification plan means the official or approved system of grouping positions into appropriate classes consisting of an index to the class specifications the class specifications and rules for administering the classification plan classified service means all fulltime and parttime offices and positions which are appointed directly or indirectly by the city manager they shall be divided into supervisory and nonsupervisory positions compensation means the standard rates of pay which have been established for the respective classes or work as set forth in the compensation plan compensation plan means the official schedule of pay approved by council assigning one or more rates of pay to each class title continuous service means employment without interruption except for absences on approved leaves or absences to serve in the armed forces of the united states demotion means assignment of an employee from one class to another which has a lower maximum rate of pay department means the primary organizational unit which is under the immediate charge of a department head who reports directly to the city manager dismissal means separation from city employment for cause eligible means a person whose name is on an appropriate employment list and who is not ineligible for appointment for other reasons eligible list means the ranking of eligibles for a vacancy in order of overall qualifications employee means an individual who is legally employed by the city and is compensated city payroll for his or her services individuals or groups compensated on a fee basis are not included the word is synonymous with incumbent examination means the process of testing evaluating or investigating the fitness and qualifications of applicants and employees grievance means a wrong real or fancied considered by an employee as grounds for complaint immediate family means spouse children mother father brother sister motherinlaw and fatherinlaw intoxication and drunkenness are synonymous and one may be said to be intoxicated when liquor has affected his faculties to such an extent as to cause him to lose self control that is normal control of his bodily and mental faculties layoff means the involuntary nondisciplinary separation of an employee from a position leave means any authorized absence during regularly scheduled working hours that has been approved by the proper authority leave may be authorized with or without pay absence without leave is considered unauthorized absence open examination means an examination open to the public and not limited to employees in city service overtime means authorized time worked by an employee in excess of his total normal working hours per week overtime pay means compensation paid to an employee for overtime work performed in accordance with these codified ordinances time appointment means an appointment which consists of less than fulltime hours and more than a twentyweek period it is less than a regular and more than a temporary appointment in relation to the amount of hours assigned time employee means an individual who works any arrangement of hours weekly for more than twenty 20 consecutive weeks such an employee is only paid for the hours he or she works time employees are not eligible for any pension benefits group health life and dental insurance sick leave or annual leave benefits pay grade means a symbol indicating the pay range of a class of positions pay rate means a specific dollar amount expressed as either an annual rate a weekly rate or an hourly rate as shown in the pay plan of the city permanent employee means an employee who has completed his designated probationary period and who occupies a permanent position a permanent employee shall also be referred to as a regular employee permanent position means a group of duties and responsibilities requiring the fulltime employment of one person for thirtyfive 35 or more hours per week on a regular schedule throughout the year position means any office or employment whether occupied or vacant fulltime or parttime consisting of duties and responsibilities assigned to one individual by competent authority position number means a number assigned each position for purposes of identification probationary period means a working test period of six months duration during which an employee is required to demonstrate his fitness by actual performance of the duties for the class to which he is appointed promotion means assignment of an employee from one class to another which has a higher maximum rate of pay reclassification means the movement of an employee to a different class because of a change in duties and responsibilities regular appointment means an appointment without time limitation or special restrictions as to continued employment to a permanent position authorized to be filled and made as a result of a certification as prescribed by these codified ordinances regular employee means an individual receiving a regular appointment in either the classified or exempt service seasonal employee means an employee who works for a set amount of time such an employee shall be considered an unclassified employee separation means leaving a position by any type of action including resignation layoff dismissal removal disability and death suspension means an enforced leave of absence for disciplinary purposes or pending investigation of charges made against an employee temporary appointment means an appointment to a position authorized to be filled for a limited period and made as a result of a certification as prescribed by these codified ordinances temporary employee means an individual whose appointment to a temporary position does not exceed nineteen 19 weeks and whose position falls under the rules of unclassified employees a temporary employee is only paid for the hours he or she works temporary position means a group of duties and responsibilities requiring the temporary employment of one person on either a fulltime or parttime hourly basis this position shall not exceed a period of nineteen 19 weeks and shall fall under the rules for unclassified service transfer means the movement of an employee within or between departments divisions or classes unclassified service means offices and positions that are appointed by council including council itself the term also includes temporary and seasonal employees vacancy means a position which has been newly established or which has been vacated by a previous incumbent workday means the scheduled number of hours an employee is required to work per day workweek means the number of days in any calendar week sunday that an employee is scheduled to work 01   declaration of policy it is the declared personnel policy of the city that a employment in the city government shall be based on merit and fitness free of personal and political considerations b conditions of employment shall encourage employees to initiate and continue efficient and economical operation of municipal business c positions with similar duties and responsibilities shall be classified and compensated on an equitable and uniform basis at the highest level consistent with the economic capability of the community d all personnel actions shall be based on a comprehensive evaluation of an individuals qualifications to perform duties and responsibilities of the position and meet working standards for municipal employees e the rights and interests of employees shall be respected consistent with the interests of the city and the public fair administration of chapters 304 f a permanent career service for all persons covered by chapters 304 shall be governed by consistent standards of professional conduct necessity for continuance of the position and sufficient funds g high morale shall be promoted by the fair administration of chapters 304 h every employee has a moral obligation and is expected to comply with the spirit and intent of this merit system 02   creation of classified civil service system there is created a classified civil service system pursuant to of the city charter 03   division of positions into classified and unclassified service all offices and positions in the city government are divided into the classified and unclassified service classified service is divided into supervisory and nonsupervisory positions 04   unclassified service the unclassified service shall include the following a all elected officials and members of boards and commissions  b persons appointed to fill vacancies in elected offices  c officials appointed by council  d volunteer personnel and personnel appointed to serve without pay fire division callmen and police division auxiliary members  e seasonal employees  f temporary employees  and g oncall employees 05   classified service the classified service includes all positions appointed by the city manager which do not fall under the unclassified service the classified service is divided into two categories supervisory and nonsupervisory these positions are identified in 06   responsibilities of city manager or designee the personnel program established by chapters 304 shall be administered by the city manager or his or her designee the city manager or his or her designee a shall develop maintain and apply procedures for the recruitment compensation promotion training and disciplining of city personnel and related aspects of personnel management  b shall develop and maintain a classification and comprehensive pay plan  and c shall develop and issue such other supplemental personnel rules as are necessary for the effective implementation of chapters 304 01   delegation of authority and records maintenance a the city manager may delegate in writing to department directors the authority to promote suspend transfer or take any other established personnel action for employees in the particular department this authority may not be redelegated by department directors and the delegation shall not change any provisions of the city charter b the city manager shall maintain an adequate record of his official acts under chapters 304 the employment record of every employee c department directors shall submit promptly data on proposed appointments status changes or separation pertaining to the classified service at such time in such form and with such supporting information as these codified ordinances prescribe or as the city manager deems necessary d the city manager shall make available to authorized persons upon request personnel records and reports authorized persons are councilmen court officers and any person designated by a court of competent jurisdiction 02   city manager covered by certain provisions of classified service the city manager is in the unclassified service but shall be considered a regular employee and shall be entitled to the benefits provided in shall be covered by  all other conditions of employment shall be specified in the city charter or by council 07   working conditionsemployee welfare the city manager shall cooperate with the employees and others to promote measures directed toward more sanitary safe and healthful working conditions toward affording better facilities for employees recreation toward greater security and economic advantage as by means of group insurance group hospital plan and credit union facilities and toward any other means of bettering the conditions and improving the morale of city employees 08   standards of conduct it shall be the duty of all employees to maintain high standards of cooperation efficiency and economy in their work any conduct which is unbecoming an employee of the city shall be grounds for disciplinary action as provided under 09   pecuniary interests prohibited a in accordance with of the city charter no officer or employee of the city shall directly or indirectly make a contract with the city or receive any commission discount bonus gift contribution or reward from or any share in the profits of any person making or performing such contract unless immediately upon learning of the existence of such contract or that such contract is proposed he or she notifies council in writing of the nature of his or her interest in such contract and abstains from doing any official act on behalf of the city with reference thereto in the case of any such interest on the part of any officer whose duty it is to sign such contract on behalf of the city the contract may be signed by any other officer of the city duly authorized by the city manager when a contractor with the city is a corporation or a voluntary stock association the ownership of less than five percent of the stock or shares actually issued shall not be considered as involving any interest in the contract within the meaning of this section and such ownership shall not affect the validity of the contract unless the owner of such stock or shares is also an officer or agent of the corporation or association or solicits or takes part in the making of the contract b in matters relating to an employees official duties no employee shall 1 appear before any agency commission board or official body of the city on behalf of any person unless specifically authorized to do so by the city manager  2 assist for compensation any person in preparation of a presentation or appearance before any agency commission board or official body of the city unless specifically authorized to do so by the city manager  or 3 engage in any contract where the contract is made or originated for the benefit of the division or department of the city in which the individual employee is employed 10   political activity it is the intent of council that city employees should not be subjected to direct or indirect political activities accordingly a all officers and employees of the city except school department employees may become candidates for nomination or election to any public office with the exception of the office of councilman of the city school department employees may become candidates for nomination or election to any public office with the exception of the office of school committeeman of the city b no officer or employee of the city shall use his official authority or influence on any other officer or employee for the purpose of interfering with an election or a nomination for office or affecting the result thereof except by casting his vote c no officer or employee of the city shall directly or indirectly coerce attempt to coerce command or advise any other such officer or employee to pay lend or contribute any part of his or her salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party committee organization agency or person for political purposes d violations of subsections b and c of this section by officers or employees of the city other than councilmen shall subject such officers or employees to the procedures set forth in e violations of subsections b and c of this section by members of council shall subject such councilmen to the procedures set forth in of the city charter 11   acceptance of workers compensation act the city elects to accept the provisions of chapters 29 to 38 inclusive of title 28 of the general laws of rhode island 195 as amended known as the workers compensation act for all employees of the city with the exception of the employees of the police and fire divisions which employees are excluded by of the general laws of rhode island 195 as amended such acceptance shall be effective  12 recruitment selection and appointment of employees   recruitment policy to most effectively serve the needs of the community it shall be the policy of the city to carry on such recruitment programs as are necessary to seek out and secure the most qualified individuals to fill positions at all levels of the city service 01   eligibility and requirements a competition for a position in the municipal service shall be open to all applicants who meet the standard qualifications for the class or position applied for and who are at least eighteen 18 years of age with the following exceptions 1 police officials who must be at least twentyone 21 years of age  and 2 temporary and seasonal employees who must be at least sixteen 16 years of age with a further exception for persons fourteen 14 and fifteen 15 years of age in accordance with applicable rhode island child labor laws and department of labor regulations who assist in the recreation department programs no person shall in any way be favored or discriminated against because of race sex religion national origin political affiliation or a physical handicap which will not interfere with the adequate performance of duties b at the time of appointment any applicant for a supervisory unclassified or parttime position must live in the city and maintain residency therein in the absence of qualified city residents for positions in the classified service the city may select nonresidents for any position in the classified service  2008  prior code  27602   applications applications for employment shall be accepted at any time as a result of a single application a candidate shall be considered for all classes of positions in which his principal qualifications might profitably be used each candidate for municipal employment shall make application on the standard form prescribed and provided by the city manager such information may be required as is deemed necessary in order to judge the applicants fitness for service in the city 03   reference checks as part of the preemployment procedure former supervisors employers for a reasonable past period and references provided by candidates on the standard application form shall be checked as a precaution against obtaining undesirable employees reference checks made by personal or telephone contact shall be documented and made a part of the applicants file these reference checks shall be completed prior to an offer of employment and the information shall be made a part of the application file all such information shall be handled as privileged information 04   competitive examinations a all applicants for positions in the classified service shall be subject to competitive examination the examination shall pertain to those matters which test fairly the capacity and fitness of the candidate to discharge efficiently the duties of the class for which the examination is held examinations may be assembled or unassembled and may include written oral physical or performance tests or any combination thereof they may take into consideration such factors as education experience aptitude knowledge character physical fitness or other qualifications which enter into the determination of the relative fitness of applicants b any domiciled resident of the city with at least five consecutive years of residency shall be accorded upon proof of residency satisfactory to the city ten additional points on any written examination for initial employment  2004   1997   1995   1993 prior code  27605   publishing notices of examinations all examinations for positions in the classified service shall be published by posting announcements of the same in the personnel office on the official departmental bulletin boards and in such other places as the city manager deems advisable including at least one newspaper of general circulation in the newport area 06   minimum passing score in all examinations including original entrance examinations candidates shall be required to attain at least a minimum rating of seventy 70 07   physical and psychiatric examinations a appointment and continued employment in the classified service shall be contingent upon the candidate or incumbent satisfactorily passing a physical examination to ensure that physical standards prescribed for the different classes of positions by the city manager are met all required examinations shall be paid for by the city and shall be given by physicians designated by the city the results of the examinations will be evaluated against the criteria of whether the person could perform the particular required duties without hazard to himself or herself or others b preemployment physical or psychiatric examinations shall be passed prior to selection for all positions in the fire division and the police division or any other position requiring a high degree of physical fitness c preemployment physical examinations for other types shall be passed prior to actual employment however these examinations may be delayed until after the appointment provided that the employment offer and appointment are made subject to satisfactorily passing the prescribed physical examination d employees may be required by the city manager to pass physical andor psychiatric examinations at any time to ensure their continued fitness for duty however such examinations shall be limited to a determination of fitness for duty 08   removal of names from consideration the city manager may remove from further consideration at any time the application of any applicant who a does not possess the minimum qualifications required for any acceptable position  b has established an unsatisfactory employment or personal record as evidenced by reference checks of such a nature as to demonstrate unsuitability for employment  c has made a false statement of any material fact or practiced deception in his application  d is afflicted with any mental or physical disqualifying disease or defect that would prevent satisfactory performance of duties  e is believed to be addicted to the habitual excessive use of drugs or intoxicants  f has been convicted of crimes other than minor traffic violations  g does not reply to a mail inquiry within ten days or does not return a telephone inquiry within two days  h fails to accept appointment within two days or to report for duty within a reasonable time prescribed in the offer  i fails to file by the announced closing date for receiving applications unless prior to such date an extension has been publicly announced 09   notification of rejection whenever the city manager determines that an application shall be rejected the applicant shall be notified in writing of such rejection applications whether accepted or rejected shall remain on file and shall not be returned applications may be disposed of from time to time when it is determined that they are of no further value to the city 10   eligibility list the personnel director shall maintain lists of candidates who have successfully completed the examination procedure the names shall be ranked on the list in the order of their total rating in the examination 11   maintenance of listspreferences a all original entrance and promotional examinations shall be conducted and graded under the direct and sole supervision of the personnel director whenever a vacant position is to be filled the responsible department director shall submit to the city manager on the prescribed form a request for certification of names of eligibles if any from the current eligibility list for the class of position to be filled the department director shall consider the candidates certified and recommend one to the city manager b preference in entrance examinations shall be granted once to qualified applicants who have been members of the united states armed forces in war time the korean war from  to   and the viet nam war from  to   the lebanon operations from  to   the grenada and panama operations from  to   and the persian gulf war from  to  to the final earned ratings of veterans in competitive examinations who receive at least the minimum required score and at least the minimum required final ratings service credits of five points will be added and ten points for those with a disability rating c in the case of ties in the final rating names shall be placed on the list in the order of ratings earned in the part of the examination given the greatest weight any remaining ties shall be broken by arranging names in the order in which the applications were received except that in promotional lists seniority shall be used for this purpose d in order of priority eligibility lists shall be reemployment promotion and original appointment e permanent employees with a satisfactory employment record who have been separated from the service fault of their own shall be placed on an appropriate reemployment list prior to any appointment by examination f employees who are still serving their probation and whose service has been terminated for lack of work or funds may have their names restored to the eligibility list on which they were first rated by the city manager g no name shall remain on an eligibility list for a period exceeding two years from the date on which it was originally established thereon by the city manager h if a vacancy occurs as a result of a resignation retirement or termination at a time when the previous eligibility list has expired and a new eligibility list for any class of position has not yet been established the city manager may for a period of time not to exceed six months permanently fill the vacancy by utilizing the previous eligibility list a vacancy may also be filled by temporary appointment with the city managers written approval i it shall be the responsibility of eligibles to notify the city manager in writing of any change of address or change affecting availability for employment however the city manager may circularize lists or use other methods to determine at any time the availability of eligibles j preference in entrance examinations shall be vacancies plus two a after interview and investigation the department head except in the department of public safety where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief shall make recommendations for appointments from among those certified and shall immediately notify the city manager of the person or persons so recommended b the department head except in the department of public safety where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief shall be allowed to select and recommend to the city manager the appointment of any of the top three candidates referred to him or her from the eligibility list established by the city manager with respect to the divisions of police and fire a promotional rating form to be established by the city manager shall be completed by three officers superior in grade to a candidate for promotion upon application of such candidate to take an examination for promotion thus with respect to the police and fire divisions the eligibility list for promotion shall be established according to the following formulas police division maximum percent written examination 80 seniority 20  100 fire division maximum percent written examination 75 seniority 25  100 seniority in promotions shall be used only to break a tie in the event two equally qualified candidates attain the same score with respect to all other departments eligibility for an department head except in the department of public safety where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief files an undesirable character report to the city manager such eligible shall have his name removed from the existing list d if after certification from a department head except in the department of public safety where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief such person refuses to accept appointment his name shall be removed from the eligibility list  1994   part 1990  prior code  27613   appointments all vacancies in the classified service shall be filled by regular appointment promotion transfer or demotion a regular appointment indicates that the employee is to work for the city on a continuing basis every regular employee shall serve a probationary period of six months after original appointment except for a police officer who shall serve a oneyear probationary period after successful graduation from the municipal police training school a police officer who may already be a graduate of the municipal police training school upon valid certification of that fact shall serve a oneyear probationary period from the time of appointment the probationary period shall be regarded as an integral part of the evaluation process and shall be utilized for closely observing the employees work for obtaining the most effective adjustment of a new employee to his position and for separating any new employee whose performance does not meet the required standards during the probationary period at least two performance ratings shall be made on all probationary employees the first report is due at the end of three months employment and the second is due at the end of the fifth month third eighth and eleventh months for those employees serving the oneyear probationary period the probationary period applicable to both new and promoted employees is an extension of the examining process it enables supervisors to observe the individual employee on the job and to determine the presence or absence of various factors necessary for successful job performance which cannot be determined or measured by preemployment examination or interview b the status of the appointment shall not be changed from probationary to regular until a certification is made by the department director to the city manager that the employees services are satisfactory an employee shall not acquire full status as a regular employee until approved by the city manager if after a period of one week the department director does not certify to regular appointment the employee shall be removed from the position immediately c employees appointed to parttime positions may receive regular or temporary appointments as appropriate d temporary appointment indicates that the employee is to work for the city for a period of less than nineteen 19 consecutive weeks prospective police officers who are attending the municipal police training school shall be considered temporary employees until successful graduation from the training school and appointment as regular police officers when the appointment of an employee is changed from temporary to regular crediting of annual leave and sick leave becomes retroactive to the date of the original appointment provided that there has been no break in service as defined in the pay of temporary employees shall be computed on an hourly basis and no pay shall be given for time not worked except as otherwise provided herein temporary employees may be separated at any time within the nineteen 19 weeks of appointment when their services are no longer required the separation is not subject to the rules under  part 1990  prior code  27614   nepotism employees shall not be employed in positions under the supervision of a member of the immediate family 15   destruction of examination papers etc the examination papers and other work of applicants for positions including any correspondence in relation thereto may be destroyed upon the expiration of the eligibility list or lists resulting from such examination 16   employee development program it shall be the responsibility of the city manager to foster and promote programs of training for the city service and inservice training of employees for the purpose of improving the quality of personal services rendered to the city and of aiding employees to equip themselves for advancement in the service the city manager shall a establish standards for training programs  b see that training is carried out as approved and have prepared certificates or other forms of recognition to persons who satisfactorily complete approved courses and programs  c provide assistance to department directors in developing and conducting training to meet the specific needs of their departments and in developing and utilizing other techniques for increasing employee efficiency  d develop supervisory and management training and other types of employee development programs common to all departments  e provide assistance to department directors in establishing standards of performance and procedures for evaluating employee efficiency  f make available information concerning requirements and training opportunities in order to guide employees in increasing their efficiency in their present positions and in preparing themselves for promotions to higher positions in the city service  and g keep a record of all approved training courses and programs and a record of employees who successfully complete such courses and programs 17 classification plan   general requirements for classification of positions all positions in the nonsupervisory classified service shall be grouped into classes and each class shall include those positions sufficiently similar as to character difficulty and responsibility that a descriptive title the same descriptive title may be used to designate each position in the class b experience etc the same level of education experience knowledge ability and other qualifications may be required of incumbents c fitness similar tests of fitness may be used to select incumbents d range of compensation the same range of compensation will apply with equity under substantially the same employment conditions 01   city manager to maintain specifications for classesannual review of specificationsenumeration of classes the city manager shall maintain and publish a complete set of specifications for all classes in the classified service such specifications shall include title class features typical tasks and minimum and desirable qualifications such specifications shall be reviewed not less than once every fiscal year with a view to maintaining their accuracy the establishment of new or revised classes or the abolishment of existing classes shall be initiated by the city manager and such classification plan shall be submitted to council for adoption by ordinance to be effective every july 1st with the adoption of the annual budget the city manager at any time and at his discretion shall determine and fix the pay of all classified positions within groups of positions whenever he or she deems it necessary whenever the duties or responsibilities of existing positions have undergone significant changes or whenever new positions are to be created 03   class specifications in determining the class to which any position shall be allocated the specification of each class shall be considered as a whole the class specifications shall be descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive the use of a particular expression or illustration as to duties qualifications or other attributes shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned if such others are similar in kind or quality and shall not limit the power of supervisors to alter the detailed tasks involved in the duties of a position qualifications expected of all incumbents of positions such as a valid drivers license if the position requires driving good physical condition freedom from disabling defects which in the opinion of the city manager would adversely affect work performance honesty sobriety courtesy and industry shall be deemed to be implied in the qualification requirements of each class even though not specifically mentioned in the class specification 04   interpretation of class specifications the class specifications shall be descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive the use of a particular expression or illustration as to duties qualifications or other attributes shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned if such others are similar in kind or quality nor to limit the power of supervisors to alter the detailed tasks involved in the duties of a position 05   allocation of positionschange of dutiesnew positions supervisors shall notify the city manager promptly of each change of duties responsibilities or work assignment whenever a new position is established supervisors shall submit in writing a comprehensive job description describing in detail the duties of such position the city manager shall thereupon investigate the actual or suggested duties and shall classify the position by assigning it to the appropriate class or initiate the establishment of a new class 06   requests for reclassification any employee who considers his position improperly classified shall first submit his request for reclassification to his supervisor who shall review such request as to its justification if the supervisor finds that there is merit in the request he shall immediately transmit his recommendation to the city manager if the supervisor finds that the request is not justified he shall so advise the employee of the decision and also of the employees right to appeal under the grievance procedure set forth in 07   method of filling reclassified positions upon the reclassification of a position from one class to another class of the same level a lower level or a higher level the method of filling the position shall be determined in accordance with the rules regarding transfers demotions or promotions as may be appropriate 08   when employee to remain in reclassified position an employee occupying a reclassified position at the same grade level shall continue in the position if the change is in class title only or if the change is in recognition of a gradual change in duties and the employee has been satisfactory or better in performance of the duties of the position 09   evidence of fitness for reclassified positions the city manager may before recognizing an employees right to retain a position reclassified to a higher level require evidence of the qualifications and fitness of the incumbent including hearings investigations and noncompetitive examinations 10 pay plan   establishment of pay plan council shall determine the pay plan in the form of a salary ordinance and may amend the plan from time to time the pay plan shall be reexamined annually by the city manager who shall submit recommendations for changes to council in making such reexamination and recommendations the city manager shall include and give appropriate consideration to the following factors a maintenance of equitable relationships between classes based on their relative duties  b the general level of rates in the appropriate labor markets for comparable work under similar working conditions  and c current recruitment and retention experiences and the citys financial position and resources 01   compensation in lieu of fees commissions etc the compensation of officers and employees as fixed or otherwise provided for by chapters 304 shall be in full payment for all official services of such officers or employees and shall be in lieu of any and all fees commissions and other compensation which may be receivable by such officers in the performance of the duties of their offices such fees commissions and compensation shall belong to the city shall be collected and accounted for by such officers and shall be paid over to the city 02   fringe benefits a not preclude the granting of open enrollment period or following a qualifying life event such as a marriage or birth of a child for new hire enrollment eligible coverage in a family or individual city group health and dental insurance plan will occur on the first day of the month following a new hires original date of city employment and upon completion of the required forms b nonunion supervisory employees shall receive  1989   1989  prior code  28007  1142009   6242009   6232010   682011   6272012   6262013   9112013   6252014   6242015   6222016   10262016   6282017   6272018   6122019   beginning rate for new employees the beginning rate for new employees will normally be the minimum rate in the established grade for his or her classification in unusual situations a pay rate above the minimum rate may be authorized to a meet difficult recruiting problems or to obtain a person with markedly superior qualifications  b correct salary inequalities or give credit for prior service  or c recognize outstanding performance 08   beginning rate for former employees a former employee who is rehired at the same grade level or at a lower grade may be appointed at any merit step rate that does not exceed the existing salary applicable to the highest step rate previously obtained as a city employee 09   requirement for pay increases for each employee to become eligible for an increase in pay the director of the department for which the employee works shall submit a written statement with a personnel evaluation form to the city manager at least twenty 20 days prior to the increase date as to the manner in which the employee has performed his assigned duties since the original appointment or last advance in pay the department directors shall submit written recommendations that the employee be granted or denied an advance in pay if the employees work has been properly and diligently performed has been satisfactory in light of the length of service in the position and has shown the improvement normally to be expected with increased periods of service and other factors considered relevant to employment the department director shall recommend that the employee be granted the next regular increase in pay if in the judgment of the department director the employees work has been below standards that are expected he shall recommend that no increase be granted the city manager shall authorize or deny pay increased for city employees as recommended by department directors unless in the employees opinion and based on supporting information the recommendation is unsound in those cases a department director shall notify the employee in writing of the recommended action including the reason therefor at the same time he notifies the city manager ordinarily salary increases shall be limited to one per year with an exception for outstanding service 10   consideration for advancement creditable employment service requirements for advancement within the pay schedule and for the other purposes specified shall be based on the employees continuous service some considerations are a leaves of absences with pay and leaves of absences of thirty 30 days or less without pay shall not interrupt continuous service and are completely creditable b absences on leave without pay in excess of thirty 30 days shall be deducted from total creditable service but shall not constitute a break in continuous service c absences for extended service in the armed forces of the united states are completely creditable in computing total service d absences without leave of one workweek or more shall interrupt continuity of service and shall be deducted from total service e leave for injury in line of duty is completely creditable 11   salary increase for exceptional service generally an employee who performs the duties and responsibilities in his or her position in an outstanding manner may be considered for an increase for exceptional service in an amount of five percent of his or her pay and this increment may be authorized for periods of three six or nine months the recommendation shall be written in detail to the city manager showing precise justification and use of strict criteria this increase shall be approved by council upon the recommendation of the city manager as standards for exceptional service the following are recommended a exceptional service means that the employee on his or her own initiative and by his or her own efforts and abilities is rendering service above the level of proficiency normally expected in the class or is producing results consistently superior to that normally expected or employees in the class b exceptional service does not include usual acts or results which are caused by unusual conditions beyond the control of the employee to which he or she demonstrated a normal reaction under the circumstances c the following are some examples of the kinds of performance which might be considered exceptional service 1 developing or discovering a concept technique practice or procedure related to the work of the class which improves the quality of the service or results in financial savings developments of this character unrelated to the employees own class or work should be recognized suggestion and award system  2 performing the work of his or her class at a standard consistently above that normally expected with resulting improvement of service or financial savings  3 consistently demonstrating ingenuity in the solution of difficult problems with resulting improvement of service or financial savings  and 4 activity in community service or professional organizations on the employees own time which contribute measurably to enhancing the prestige of the public service 12   pay rates after promotion demotion or transfer when an employee is promoted demoted or transferred his or her rate of pay in the new position shall be established in accordance with the following a upon promotion an employee shall be placed in the first step of his or her new pay grade except that in cases where the first step should not be a onestep increase the promoted employee shall be placed in such step in the new pay grade as may be necessary to give a onestep increase a fire captain fire lieutenant police captain police lieutenant or police sergeant shall reach his maximum salary upon satisfactory completion of his six months probationary period b upon demotion an employee normally shall receive a onestep decrease in pay however it shall be the responsibility of the city manager in each instance to determine the amount of the pay decrease if any upon demotion of an employee c when an employee is transferred from a position of one class to a position of another class at the same grade he or she shall continue to be paid at the same step 13   service in armed forces any employee who leaves the city service to enter the armed forces and is reinstated to his previous position or its equivalent shall be paid at least the same step rate received at the time of entrance into the armed forces he or she may be granted additional step rates if he or she has gained appropriate experience in the armed forces 14 a   effective date of salary increases a when the application of these pay rules results in a supervisor for an extended period of time receiving a pay rate less than an employee under his or her supervision the city manager may authorize an increase to any step rate considered appropriate to correct this inequity b all pay increases shall be effective not earlier than the first day of the next pay period following approval 14 b c   police and fire details beyond normal police and fire hours and functions all members of the permanent police division and permanent fire division who are assigned or who volunteer for details approved or ordered by the chief of police or the fire chief when such details are for a private activity and paid out of private funds as compared to a governmental activity shall be remunerated at the following rates of pay except for jazz folk music cultural and drama festivals noncivic details and dine and dance details a members of the permanent police division shall receive the rate of pay as outlined in the agreement between the city and lodge no 8 fraternal order of police b members of the permanent fire division shall receive the rate of pay as outlined in the agreement between the city and local 108 iaff c police sergeants captains shall receive the patrolmans rate unless the detail specifically requires a ranking officer as determined by the chief of police d fire lieutenants and fire captains shall receive the firefighters rate unless the detail specifically requires a ranking officer as determined by the fire chief e for jazz folk music cultural and drama festivals and noncivic details all members of the permanent police division and permanent fire division who are assigned by the chief of their respective divisions shall be paid at one and onehalf times their regular hourly rate f for dine and dance details all members of the permanent police division who are assigned by the chief of police shall be paid the rates as stated above g for assignments such as election duty presidential detail and other types of public functions apply 15   pay differential for certain fire personnel fire division personnel who are assigned to work five eighthour shifts per week shall receive compensation as outlined in the agreement between council and local 108 iaff aflcio 16   uniform allowances a a uniform allowance shall be paid to each member of the division of fire as outlined in the agreement between council and local 108 iaff aflcio b a uniform allowance shall be paid to each member of the division of police as outlined in the agreement between the city and the fraternal order of police lodge no 8 17   authorized deductions deductions for various reasons shall be made from an employees pay after written authorization of the individual employee has been filed with the city the deductions shall be for union dues hospitalization and savings bonds the number of different deductions shall be limited by the mechanical ability of the finance department from time to time compensation paid to employees shall be subject to a deduction for the tax under the federal insurance contribution act social security except police and fire division employees under a pension plan 18 promotions transfers and demotions   promotions a promotions within service promotions shall be from within service if possible qualified employees shall be considered for promotion to fill any vacant position in the classified service before outside applicants are considered b procedure for union transfers a transfer of an employee from one position to another without change in grade may be effected when 1 the employee meets the qualification requirements  2 it is in the best interests of the city  3 further training and development of an employee in another position would be beneficial to future staffing potential of the city  4 it meets a personal need of the employee and is consistent with paragraphs 1 and 2 of this subsection a b transfer of an employee from one position to another may be effected on a temporary basis because of an emergency and the employees grade may be increased for the time during the emergency when the interest of the city is served c transfers from the police and fire divisions of personnel covered by respective pension rights are prohibited except with the consent of the individual transfers into the police and fire divisions to positions covered by the respective pension plan shall follow the established procedures for appointment to these divisions 02   demotions an employee may be demoted to a position of a lower grade for which he or she is qualified for any of the following reasons a when he or she would otherwise be laid off because his or her position is reclassified to a lower grade  because of lack of work  because of lack of funds  or because of the return to work from authorized leave of another employee to such position in accordance with the rules on leave  b when he or she does not possess the necessary qualifications to render satisfactory service in the position he or she holds or when removed during probation  or c when or she voluntarily requests such demotion 03 working hours   normal workweek the number of hours an employee is required to be on duty each day week or month shall as far as practical be uniform for all regular employees in the same class the normal workweek for regular employees in different classes shall be a fire division in the fire division the regular work schedule shall be a total of fortytwo 42 hours per week sunday  including meal and rest periods for employees whose regular duties are principally the prevention or extinguishing of fires but who are on call at any time for necessary duty b police division the regular work schedule for policemen shall consist of four consecutive days of work followed by two consecutive days off the regular workday for such policemen shall comprise a tour of duty of eight and onehalf hours less onehalf hour for lunch this will include a onehalf hour overlap of shifts the above schedule is for employees in the police division whose regular duties are principally the prevention or investigation of crime but who are on call at any time for necessary duty c police and fire chiefs the fire and police chiefs are scheduled for forty 40 hours per week sunday  consisting of five consecutive workdays of eight hours each but such chiefs shall be on call at anytime for necessary duty d employees on sevenday rotating schedule a total of forty 40 hours per week sunday  are scheduled for all employees working on a rotating schedule for activities required to be covered on a sevenday week schedule e city hall administrative and clerical employees a total of thirtyfive 35 hours per week monday  are scheduled for all city hall and administrative and clerical employees of the various departments f others a total of forty 40 hours per week sunday  consisting of five consecutive work days of eight hours each are scheduled for all other employees g deviations the scheduled workweek of an individual employee shall normally be established consistent with the above workweek for his particular organizational unit however the city manager may approve deviations from the normal scheduled workweek of an individual employee to suit the needs of the city so long as the weekly total is observed 01   inclusion of meal periods as part of workweek the city manager may authorize the inclusion of the meal period as time actually worked for shifttype positions 02   overtime a overtime work shall be kept to a minimum and authorized by the city manager or his designee only under circumstances which call for immediate action or in special situations due to the nature of the operation or status of the activity except as hereinafter otherwise provided no employer shall employ an individual for a workweek longer than the regularly scheduled workweek unless the employee is compensated at a rate of one and onehalf times the regular rate at which he or she is employed for all hours worked in excess of regularly scheduled hours per week b seasonal temporary and parttime employees shall be compensated at the rate of one and onehalf times the regular rate for all hours worked in excess of forty 40 hours per week such an employee shall be scheduled for at least three hours work at the beginning of a shift or be paid not less than three times his or her regular hourly rate c supervisory employees who make more than two hundred dollars $2000 per week shall not receive compensation for overtime hours worked such employees may be credited with and granted some compensatory leave for such overtime provided that such time off does not exceed the actual hours worked d upon written recommendation of the department director and at the discretion of the city manager an employee who performs authorized overtime work for which the city is reimbursed by a private contractor may be paid at the employees straighttime rate in lieu of being given compensatory time off if it is impossible to grant compensatory time off without seriously disrupting the department work schedule  1990  prior code  28403   standby pay standby pay shall be compensated in accordance with the is incapacitated for the performance of his or her duties by sickness injury confinement or medical dental or optical examination or treatment  b when a member of the immediate family of the employee is afflicted with a contagious disease requiring isolation quarantine or restriction of movement for a particular period and requiring the care and attendance of the employee  and c through exposure to contagious disease the presence of the employee at his post of duty would jeopardize the health of others 09   accrual of sick leave fulltime employees shall accrue sick leave as follows a
