advance sick leave not to exceed four workweeks may be granted by the city manager to regular employees after the first six months of employment in cases of serious disability or ailments when it is to the advantage of the city to do so this authority may not be delegated b advance sick leave may be granted irrespective of whether or not the employee has annual leave to his credit c requests for advance sick leave shall be submitted in writing stating the circumstances and the need for such leave the time and date when the accrued sick leave will be exhausted the amount of advance sick leave requested and the date to which such leave will extend d requests for advance sick leave shall be evaluated against the following considerations 1 the employees past leave record  2 the nature seriousness and extent of illness or disability  3 the probability of return to duty and prospect for continued employment  4 the probability of the employee liquidating the leave to be advanced e individuals who upon separation from city employment are indebted for advance sick leave shall reimburse the city or appropriate deductions shall be made from his or her salary or any leave due him or her this requirement may be waived in cases of separation for a serious illness which does not include maternity situations or disability which is confirmed by the statement of a licensed physician 12   absence on nonworkdays sick leave shall not be debited for absence on observed holidays or other nonworkdays 13   reports and investigationsmedical certificatesfraud reporting and investigating sickness together with other miscellaneous factors relative to sick leave shall be handled as follows a reporting of sickness employees except police and fire employees who are absent from duty for reasons which entitle them to sick leave shall ensure that their respective supervisors are notified within two hours after their usual reporting time if physically able to do so upon return to work the employee shall immediately submit to his supervisor an authorization for leave form police and fire employees shall notify their respective supervisors before their scheduled duty b medical certificate a medical statement may be required for any absence chargeable to sick leave  such statement shall normally be required for sick leave in excess of five workdays c false or fraudulent use of sick leave the city may investigate any absence for which sick leave is requested false or fraudulent use of sick leave shall be cause for dismissal or appropriate disciplinary action against the offending employee 14   leave for injury or illness in line of duty leave for absence with compensation as provided by the provisions of chapters 29 inclusive of title 28 of the general laws of rhode island 195 as amended know as the workers compensation act shall be granted to permanent employees who become incapacitated as a result of injury or occupational disease incurred misconduct of their own while during actual performance of duty compensation shall consist of payment of all bills incurred as a direct and necessary result of such injury which bills are not compensable by any insurer or voluntary health program such leave shall start at such time as the employee is unable to perform his customary duties every application for such leave shall contain a statement by the employee affirmed by his supervisor setting forth the details of the accident and supported by the certificate of a licensed physician setting forth the nature and extent of the leave for injury in the line of duty the employers first report of injury form dwc1 shall be submitted by the department head within twentyfour 24 hours of the injury for approval by the insurer named by the city every period of leave granted under this section shall be considered creditable service and shall be recorded on the employees leave card but shall not be charged to any other type of leave  1996   military leave a as used in this section military duty means 1 training and service performed by an inductee enlistee or reservist or any entrant into a temporary component of the armed forces of the united states  2 time spent in returning for and returning from such training and service or if a rejection occurs from the place of reporting therefor  and 3 active duty training as a reservist in the armed forces of the united states where the call is for training only b any regular employee who leaves the city service for military duty shall be placed on military leave without pay such leave to extend date forty 40 days after his release or hospitalization continuing after release for not more than one year c a regular employee shall also be granted a leave of absence for the purpose of being inducted or otherwise entering military duty if not accepted for such duty the employee shall be reinstated in his position without loss of seniority or status and without reduction in his rate of pay during such period the employee shall for all purposes be considered to have rendered service and to have been compensated therefore at his regular rate of pay d such an employee as mentioned in subsections b and c of this section shall be entitled to restoration provided he makes application therefor within forty 40 days after the date of his release from duty under conditions other than dishonorable and is physically and mentally capable of performing the duties of the position involved e an employee returning from military service shall normally be restored to the position which he vacated upon entering the military service in the event that the vacated position no longer exists at the time he qualifies for return to work such person shall be entitled to be reemployed in another existing position of the same class specification provided such reemployment does not necessitate the laying off of another person with greater seniority f a regular employee who leaves the service directly for military leave without pay may elect to be paid for any accrued annual personal or compensatory leave as he may be entitled to if he were actually separating from the city service his decision shall be noted on the personnel action form effecting the leave if the employee elects not to be paid for such leave the accrued leave credits shall be reinstated upon return of the employee g employees restored to duty under this section shall have unused sick leave credits restored for their use 20   annual leave for reservists compensation a regular employee who is a member of any reserve component of the united states armed forces will be allowed leave of absence for required training or duty without loss of pay for a single period each year not exceeding two calendar weeks in the event that the time of such training is optional the time shall be designated at the discretion of the city by loss of pay it is meant that the city shall make up the difference of the pay received from military training and the employees normal salary 21   deferment from service in order to ensure uniformity requests for deferment of employees from service in the armed forces shall be made only by the city manager 22   compensation upon return if in the opinion of the city manager the military duties of an employee on military leave were closely related to his duties as a city employee and constituted an addition to his training and experience for city work the employee when returned from his military leave may be given a pay rate not higher than that which he would have attained had he remained in continuous employment 23   leave without pay the city manager may grant regular employees leave without pay for a period not to exceed one year subject to the following conditions a leave without pay may be granted only when it is in the interests of the city to do so the needs of the employee shall be considered when he has shown by his record to be of more than average value to the city and when it is desirable to retain the employee even at some sacrifice b during an employees approved leave of absence his position may be filled by temporary appointment a temporary promotion or detail of another employee at the expiration of a leave without pay the employee has the right to and shall be reinstated in the position he vacated if the position still exists or if not to any other vacant position in the same class if this is not possible he shall be transferred to another position for which he qualifies and for which a vacancy exists or normal layoff procedures shall be used to assign the employee to a position or to determine which employee shall be separated c approved leave without pay shall not constitute a break in service d failure on the part of the employee to report promptly at the expiration of a leave without pay may be cause for dismissal e with respect to benefits including salary and wages paid by the city to any employee pursuant to the above the city shall be subrogated to all rights the employee may have against any person causing the amount paid by the city f when injury leave is used the employee shall receive the difference between the workmens compensation insurance payments and his regular salary if any 24   holidays a the following holidays are observed by the city and shall be granted to all employees 25 b it shall be the police of the city to ensure that all regular employees enjoy the same number of holidays each year they will be celebrated by regular employees working a thirtyfive 35 or forty 40 hour week monday for these groups when a holiday falls on a saturday it shall be observed on the preceding friday when a holiday falls on a sunday the following monday shall be observed as the holiday for regular employees on a workweek of other than monday the city manager shall designate the workday that shall be observed members of the police and fire divisions and all other employees who are on a sevenday rotating shift shall receive holiday pay in lieu of time off this holiday pay shall be onefifth the employees weekly salary and shall be paid to each employee over and above his or her biweekly salary the pay period in which the holiday occurs whether he or she is scheduled to work the holiday or not c time employees shall be paid for observed holidays which fall on days for which they would otherwise be scheduled to work according to the number of hours for which they are scheduled to work on that day d in order to receive pay for an observed holiday an employee must be in a work or paid leave status either his scheduled workday immediately preceding or following the holiday and not have been absent without authorization either the workday before or after the holiday e the appointment or separation of a regular employee shall not be effected on a day to be observed as a holiday except when the employee works that day 25   civil leave an employee shall be given necessary time off without loss of pay when a performing jury duty  however jury fees received other than meal or travel allowances shall be returned to the city  b required by duties or subpoenaed to appear before a court public body or commission as a witness on behalf of the city because of his or her official capacity with the city  c performing emergency civilian duty in connection with national defense  or d for the purpose of voting when the polls are not open at least one hour before or after the employees scheduled hours of work 26   administrative emergency leave the city manager may excuse employees from duty in emergency situations for short periods of time examples of emergencies are extreme weather conditions disaster such as fire flood or other natural phenomena which prevent employees from working or reporting to work breakdown of machines and emergency rescue or protection work 27   unauthorized absences a an employee who is absent from duty without approval shall 1 receive no pay for the duration of the absence  and 2 be subject to dismissal or other appropriate disciplinary action b it is recognized that there may be extenuating circumstances for unauthorized absence and due consideration shall be given each case as to the type of leave to be approved or other appropriate disciplinary action c failure of an employee to report for work at the expiration of an authorized leave or to request an extension of such leave shall be considered an absence without leave d under ordinary circumstances unavoidable or necessary absence from duty of less than one hour or tardiness may be excused without charge to leave if such absence or tardiness can be fully justified by the employee to his supervisors satisfaction otherwise such absence shall be handled administratively by requiring additional work or by a charge against compensatory time which the employee may have to his or her credit or by charging the time to the employees leave account if the employee is tardy the supervisor shall determine the cause of the tardiness in order to plan with the employee the corrective steps to be taken 28   maternity leave employees who have completed two years of service with the city shall be granted a leave of absence without pay or any benefits for maternity written application for maternity leave must be filed with the personnel director at least sixty 60 days prior to the start of such leave an employee who wishes to work beyond the fourth month of pregnancy must file a doctors certificate with the personnel director maternity leave shall not exceed six months if an employee has not returned to fulltime city employment at the end of the six months maternity leave it shall be considered an automatic resignation temporary replacements for employees on maternity leave shall not be covered by this section an employee shall notify the personnel director two weeks prior to the end of the six months leave if she expects to return to duty 29   death leave a leave for death in the immediate family shall be granted for a period not to exceed three days such leave shall not be charged to any other type of leave b additional leave when required shall be charged to annual leave c leave for death in the immediate family for members of council 94 will be in accordance with the agreement between council and public employees council 94 d leave for death for members of local no 108 iaff shall be in accordance with the agreement between the council and local no 108 iaff e leave for death for members of lodge no 8 fraternal order of police shall be in accordance with the agreement between council and such lodge 30   leave for union business reasonable leave shall be granted for the conduct of union business and such leave shall not be charged to any other type of leave 31   procedure for requesting leave a for all leave other than official holiday sick and administrative emergency leave and leave for death in the family a written request indicating the kind of leave the duration and the dates of departure and return must be approved prior to the taking of leave the request for leave should be submitted prior to beginning the leave in the case of sick leave the leave form shall be completed and submitted for approval immediately upon the employees return to duty b unless an absence is substantiated by a leave form approved by the city manager or his designee an employee shall not be paid for any absence from scheduled work hours 32 separations and disciplinary actions   return of records etc resignation and retirement a purpose to set forth administrative guidelines for the proper and timely separation from service for employees of the city b policy when a city employee leaves municipal service of his or her own volition a number of administrative tasks are required including but not limited to computing any earned severance benefits initiating process for pension benefits reclaiming and cataloguing any cityissued equipment or inventorying other property formally issued to the employee for which the city claims or retains ownership the enactment of an employee separation process will expedite the formal notification of appropriate supervisors and department heads of an impending employee separation and subsequent work force vacancy this procedure is intended to provide reasonable and adequate notice of an employee departure to appropriate city supervisors and administrators and is not intended to supersede contradict or circumvent any codified employee protection right or privilege further it is not intended to limit alter or restrict any state or federal employee protection or law or provision of an employees collective bargaining agreement c procedure prior to resigning or retiring from city employment an employee must provide a letter to his or her department head indicating the employees intention to leave service and specifying the employees last projected date of work subsequently the department head shall prepare an employee separation report and forward the same with the employees letter to the human resources administrator with such notification from the employee the department head shall also execute appropriate departmentlevel internal procedures to separate the employee from service such as inspecting collecting and cataloguing from the employee all departmentissued equipment and other property belonging to the city with receipt of the employee separation report the human resources administrator shall schedule an exit interview with the employee at which time the employee will be provided with information concerning severance postemployment benefits obligations andor duties subsequently the employee separation report will be forwarded to the city manager for approval the form shall specify circumstances benefits contingencies andor conditions related to the employees separation  consistent with provisions of the city of newport codified ordinances ri general laws and the employees employment conditions including provisions of any applicable collective bargaining agreement failure on the part of an employee to submit a letter of intended separation from employment or delays in the completion of employee separation report or the subsequent exit interview may create administrative delays in the computation and delivery of severance and postemployment benefits for the employee leaving city service  2006   layoff a when a position is discontinued or abolished because of a change in duties reorganization lack of work or lack of funds the department director shall submit a report to the city manager together with a recommendation as to whether or not the employee should be laid off b the city manager shall determine the order of layoff of employees on the basis of seniority that is those with the least seniority shall be laid off first insofar as job classification permits whenever it becomes necessary to increase the working forces laidoff employees shall be recalled in reverse order of their layoff before any new help is hired c regular employees subject to layoff shall be notified in writing two calendar weeks prior to the effective date whenever possible d employees who are laid off shall upon request be placed on the open examination list for any class for which they are qualified 04   dismissal a the city manager may dismiss any employee for the good of the city service for any of the following reasons 1 failure to meet prescribed standards of work morality and ethics to an extent that makes an employee unsuitable for any kind of employment in the city service  2 theft or destruction of city property  3 incompetency inefficiency or negligence in the performance of duties  4 insubordination that constitutes a serious breach of discipline  5 conviction of a criminal offense  6 notoriously disgraceful personal conduct  7 unauthorized absences or abuse of leave privileges  8 acceptance of any valuable consideration which was given with the expectation of influencing the employee in the performance of his duties  9 falsification of records or use of official position for personal advantage b the employee shall be furnished an advance written notice containing the nature of the proposed action the reasons therefor and his or her right to answer the charges orally or in writing this notice shall be furnished at least one calendar week prior to the proposed effective date of the action c during the advance notice period the employee may be retained in duty status placed on leave or suspended with or without pay at the discretion of the city manager d if the employee fails to respond to the advance notice the proposed action of the city manager shall be effective on the date specified with no need for further action otherwise the city manager shall carefully consider the reply of the employee before making a final decision and at the earliest possible moment shall transmit to the employee a letter containing his final decision e it is the policy of the city not to rehire former employees who have been dismissed or who resigned while charges where pending under this section 05   termination of regular appointment during probationary period a at any time during the probationary period the city manager may separate an employee whose performance does not meet the required standards b department heads shall inform employees in writing of the evaluation of their performance prior to completion of the probationary period however an employee shall not acquire full status as a regular employee until approved by the city manager c the reasons for the removal shall be furnished the employee verbally and confirmed in writing 06   removal for disability an employee may be separated for disability when he or she cannot perform the required duties because of physical or mental impairment action may be initiated by the employee his or her legal representative or the city but in all cases such action must be supported by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager the city may require an examination at its expense and performed by a physician of its choice 07   death separation shall be effective as of the date of death 08   payment of compensation to estate all compensation due in accordance with be paid to the estate of the employee except for such sums as by law may be paid to the surviving spouse 09   disciplinary actions whenever employee performance attitude work habits or personal conduct at any time falls below a desirable level supervisors shall inform them promptly and specifically of such lapses and give counsel and assistance if appropriate and justified a reasonable period of time for improvement may be allowed before initiating a disciplinary action in some instances a specific incident may justify severe disciplinary action in and of itself however the action to be taken depends on the seriousness of the incident and the whole pattern of the employees past performance and conduct 11   written reprimand in situations where an oral warning has not resulted in expected improvements or where more severe initial action is warranted a written reprimand shall be sent to the employee and a copy shall be placed in the employees personnel folder 12   suspension without pay an employee may be suspended without pay for reasons of misconduct negligence inefficiency insubordination disloyalty unauthorized absence or other justifiable reasons when alternate personnel actions are not appropriate the employee shall be furnished an advance written notice except as provided below containing the nature of the proposed action the reasons therefor and his right to answer the charges orally or in writing this notice shall be furnished at least twentyfour 24 hours prior to the proposed effective date of the action if the employee fails to respond to the advance notice the proposed action shall be effective on the date specified with no need for future action if the employee replies his answer shall be carefully considered before a decision is reached a final written decision shall be furnished an immediate suspension may be made when the city manager determines that it is in the best interest of the city justification for such action may include but is not limited to shortage of funds unlawful use of property insubordination intoxication on duty or arrest for a crime 13 employee grievance procedure   statement of policy the most effective accomplishment of the work of the city requires prompt consideration and equitable adjustment of employee grievances it is the desire of the city to adjust grievances informally and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise however it is recognized that there will be occasional grievances which will be resolved only after a formal appeal and review accordingly the following procedure is established to ensure fair and impartial review a members of the bargaining unit established by the state labor relations board in certification no ee 1764 shall following the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the council and the state public employee council no 94 b members of the bargaining unit represented by the newport lodge no 8 fraternal order of police shall follow the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the city and newport lodge no 8 fraternal order of police c members of the bargaining unit represented by local no 108 international association of firefighters aflcio shall follow the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the city and local no 108 iaff aflcio 01   general procedure a the aggrieved employee or his representative shall take up his or her grievance with his or her immediate supervisor who shall take the necessary steps to adjust the complaint if it is within his or her power to do so b if the immediate supervisor is unable or unwilling to adjust the grievance the grievance shall be put into writing and sent to his or her division or department head with a copy to the department of personnel the department or division head shall discuss the grievance with the employee and his or her representatives if any and attempt to adjust the problem if it is within his or her power to do so the division or department head shall reduce his or her findings in the case to writing within two days and advise the employee and the personnel department of his or her decision in the case c should the employee andor the union representing such employee still be grieved the employee andor the union representing such employee should apply in writing to the city manager stating the reasons for his or her grievance including all pertinent facts of the case d within ten days after receiving the complaint the city manager shall call a meeting which shall include the department head the complainant and representatives of his or her own choosing and any other person or persons involved in the complaint the city manager shall preside at the meeting and hear the entire case to obtain all the facts e the city manager shall make a complete report of his or her findings and render a decision to the employee and department head in writing f the personnel appeals board may review the decision of the city manager and its decision shall be final 02 consultant services   statement of policies it is the policy of the city to retain consultant services when necessary on the basis of demonstrated competence and qualification for the type of services required at fair and reasonable prices it is recognized that competence experience and ability are important considerations and that the amount of the fee shall not be the only criterion in selecting professional services it is further the policy of the city to give first preference where the talents and experience are available and previous evaluation is satisfactory to the selection of consulting services of firms or principals located in the city and second preference to statebased firms or principals 01   classification of services a class i class i service is service for projects where the consultants fee will exceed ten thousand dollars $1000000 the consultant shall be recommended by a staff screening and selection committee with final selection and contract approval to be accomplished by council at a regular or special council meeting members of the committee shall be the city manager the director of engineering and inspections the director of finance and the department head requesting the service the city solicitor shall also serve as a member of the committee for the purpose of reviewing the legality of all proposed contracts b class ii class ii service is service for projects where the consultants fee will not exceed ten thousand dollars $1000000 the city manager is authorized to select consultants based upon the department heads recommendation a full report of all consultant screening and selection shall be contained in the city managers report to council 02   general procedures and responsibilities the procedures and responsibilities outlined herein provide a general scope of the procedures for consultant selection detailed instructions and guidelines are contained in a project initiation when a department head identifies a project for which class i consultant service will be necessary he or she shall draft a scope of service for the specific project the scope of service shall be submitted to the city manager for approval and for certification that funds are available in the budget for the service the scope of service shall then be presented to council for authorization to initiate the project b roster of consultants upon authorization to initiate the project the city manager shall prepare a roster of firms interested in providing this type of service to the city the roster shall be established and maintained using information set forth in c expressions of interest the city manager shall contact those persons or firms on the consultants roster for a written expression of interest on the specific project the request should invite interest in the project and comment by the date set forth in the request as to the special expertise in the project being considered and the availability of the firm or person to provide the required service d initial screening and request for proposals the expression of interest shall then be presented to the staff screening and selection committee for initial screening in accordance with the guidelines provided in where possible the committee shall designate at least three firms who shall be requested to present in person detailed proposals on the project detailed proposals shall include data as suggested in the guidelines in e final selection and contract negotiation on the basis of the detailed proposals presented by the prospective consultants the committee shall recommend a consultant and a form of written contract to council if for some reason the committee cannot agree the city manager shall make a recommendation to council council shall approve or disapprove the selection and contract 03   detailed guidelines for consultant selection a scope of services the scope of services for the particular project shall be developed by the department requesting the service the scope should define the project in specific terms and identify the various project components and phases the degree if any of federal or state participation should also be defined at this time since certain planning and design criteria may be prerequisites for federal or state assistance a memorandum transmitting the scope of services to the city manager for presentation to council should define the need for the project identify a budget estimate for the project and suggest the source of funds for payment to the consultant b organization of screening committee the city manager shall serve as chairman of the staff screening and selection committee and the director of finance as vicechairman the department head requesting the project or his or her representative shall attend all committee meetings to provide data and recommendations on the project and to implement actions directed by the committee c expression of interest letters requesting an expression of interest should ask the consultants to indicate their interest in the particular project set forth special qualifications they may wish to call to the attention of the committee describe previous experience with similar jobs and indicate their capability to perform the service within any time limitations if the consultant does not have a brochure or resume on file he or she should be asked to present that information d initial screening the committee shall review the expressions of interest and other qualification data on file with the city factors to be determined in initial screening shall include 1 specialized experience in the type of work required  2 a record of the firm in accomplishing work on other projects in the required time  3 the quality of work previously performed by the firm for the city  4 the professional background experience and expertise of principals and potential project managers  5 recent experience showing accuracy of cost estimates  6 community relations including evidence of sensitivity to citizen concerns  and 7 the geographic location of the principal offices of the firm e detailed proposals based on the results of the initial screening not more than three firms shall be invited to submit a detailed proposal firms not asked to submit a detailed proposal should be so advised in writing and thanked for the their interest in the project 1 firms submitting detailed proposals should be asked to provide a resume of their proposed project supervisor the name of the principal who would be responsible for the work the amount of work presently under way the ability of the firm to meet required time schedules a description of how the project would be conducted and monitored an evaluation of the adequacy of funds available to accomplish the proposed project the proposed method of determining fees with alternatives if desired the amount of administrative assistance during the first phases of the project and the amount of supervision during the construction phase of the project as well as other facts they wish to present in favor of their firm 2 the contract form for consulting services should in general follow the standards of the american institute of architects the national society of professional engineers or the american society of civil engineers as applicable to the specific project 3 these firms shall also be advised that city policy requires that an equal employment opportunity and affirmative action program be provided prior to execution of a contract f interview and selection upon receipt of the detailed proposals the staff selection and screening committee shall be convened to review the proposals interview the prospective consultants review fee determination methods and rank the consultants for negotiation of fees association consultants who would be used by the primary consultant should be identified at this time selection for negotiation should be based upon qualifications availability staffing professional competence and such other matters as the committee may deem proper g contract negotiation the selected firm shall then be requested to come in for a final conference with the responsible department head to define precisely the scope of service to be provided and to submit a proposal covering the compensation requirements for the work consultant firms employing four or more people shall also be required to submit their equal employment opportunity and affirmative action program at this time a fee shall then be negotiated with the funds available for the project and a contract shall be prepared and submitted to the city solicitor for review and then submitted to the city manager for presentation to council for approval if after reasonable effort a contract cannot be negotiated within available funds the negotiations with the designated consultant shall be terminated in writing and negotiations shall be started with the next consultant recommended h contract approval the final action to implement consultant selection is approval of the consultant contract all contracts are to be approved by council after thorough review by the city solicitor i consultant records upon completion or termination of a contract the department responsible for the project shall submit a one page summary evaluation of the consultants handling of the project which evaluation shall include the following data 1 the name of the consultant  2 the date of the contract and the date of completion  3 the cost as stated in the initial contract the amount paid and the reason for any difference  4 the names of key personnel working on the project  5 the special strengths exhibited by the consultant  6 the problems or weaknesses in the consultants handling of the project  7 the title and date of any report documents prepared by the consultant  8 adherence to the time schedule by the consultant  and 9 any comment on commitment to equal employment opportunity the summary evaluation shall be submitted to the city manager for review and subsequent filing with the consultants resume in the city managers office summary evaluations shall be retained for a period of five years the summary evaluation shall be reported to council by the city manager 04   contract extensionsexceptions to regulations a notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter where the scope of services states that the project may include additional services which are a logical extension of the original services and if continuation or extension of the project is economically feasible and the evaluation of services performed to date is satisfactory the city manager with the final approval of council may negotiate the continued employment of the same consultant without following procedural steps set forth in a f b notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter council may by resolution authorize the city manager to negotiate the employment of a consultant without following the steps set forth in this chapter for reasons of economy or expediency or because selection of a consultant by following such steps would be for any reason impractical 05 retirement   notice of retirement the provisions of f the applicant may choose to defer either fifty 50 percent or one hundred 100 percent of the annual tax at his or her option g the deferred tax shall become a lien upon the property and the applicant may remove the lien at any time by paying the amount due in full plus interest the lien shall be recorded by the city clerk and shall continue until discharged by full payment of all deferred taxes and all interest thereon h interest on deferred taxes shall accrue at the rate set forth under the state of rhode island regulations i deferments of taxes will be granted if the application is program a established a senior resident property tax service credit program is established beginning  to allow qualified senior residents as determined by the provisions of this section to receive limited real estate tax credits in exchange for services provided to the city of newport municipal government as described in this section b age and income limits taxpayers qualifying for a senior resident property tax service credit must be sixtyfive 65 years of age or over by july 1st to earn property tax credit relief under this program reside at the property as a fulltime resident or residents and have a gross annual income from all sources at or below the moderateincome level for newport county for the previous calendar year as published by the us department of housing and urban development for a twoperson household for jointly held property or in the case of a single person at or below the published level as aforementioned for a oneperson household c ownership the taxpayer or taxpayers applying for the senior resident property tax service credit program must be the owner of the respective real estate to which the credit will apply if the property is held in trust the beneficiary or beneficiaries of the trust must be the taxpayer or taxpayers applying for the senior resident property tax service credit program d maximum abatement and hourly rate the maximum credit taxpayers may earn is five hundred dollars $50000 per fiscal year credit for service will be at the state of rhode island hourly minimum wage at the time the service is performed e personal exemptions and deferrals taxpayers may earn tax credits under the service credit program in addition to any property tax exemptions for which they may be eligible under other statutes or city ordinances f adoption of local program rules the city manager may establish rules and procedures for the senior property tax service credit program these rules and procedures will assure coordination of the assignment of program participants to the various municipal departments where they will perform their services g certification of service the board officer or department supervising the senior taxpayers service must certify to the assessor the hours of service performed by the taxpayer before the actual tax for the fiscal year is committed the certification must state the amount actually earned as of that time services performed after that date shall be credited toward the next fiscal years actually tax bill to the extent they are consistent with the program rules established by the city manager a copy of the certification must also be provided to the senior program participant prior to the actual tax bill being issued h status of volunteers senior taxpayers performing services in return for property tax reductions shall be considered employees for the purposes of municipal tort liability the city will be liable for damages for injuries to third parties and for indemnification of the seniors to the same extent as they are in the case of injuries caused by regular municipal employees  2006   2004   exemptionsconditions a pursuant to of the public laws of department heads submitting agencies and the city manager in determining priorities of projects utilizing the following a will the project contribute to protection of life and property and to conservation of community resources b what is the relationship of the project to the welfare and progress of the entire community c how will the residents be affected by the project how many will be benefitted or harmed if the project is or is not carried out d will the improvements replace existing facilities that are obsolete or is the item new e will the project add to the value of the area and increase the valuation of the city and private property f will the improvements reduce or increase current operating costs g what social aesthetic or environmental values will be enhanced by completion of the project 24 d   capital improvement programsubmittalcontents a not later than october 15th of each year all city departments and agencies shall submit requests for capital improvement maintaining licensed premises contiguous sidewalks and adjacent parking lots used for licensed premises in a neat and orderly condition j noise this subsection is derived from compliance with the provisions of this subsection shall not relieve any person from otherwise complying with such chapter in its entirety 1 findingsintent the board finds and declares that a excessive noise is a serious hazard to the public health and welfare and the quality of life in a close urban society b a substantial body of science and technology exists by which excessive noise can be substantially abated without serious inconvenience to the public c certain of the noise producing equipment in this community is essential to the quality of life herein and should be allowed to continue at reasonable levels with moderate regulation d each person has a right to an environment reasonably free from noise which jeopardizes health or welfare or unnecessarily degrades the quality of life e it is the declared policy of the city to promote an environment free from excessive noise otherwise properly called noise pollution which unnecessarily jeopardizes the health and welfare and degrades the quality of the lives of the residents of this community without unduly prohibiting limiting or otherwise regulating the function of certain noise producing equipment which is not amendable to such controls and yet is essential to the economy and qualify of life of the community 2 purpose the purpose of this subsection is to establish standards for the control of noise pollution in the city by setting maximum permissible sound levels for various activities related to establishments holding class a b and c liquor licenses 3 measurement of sound a if the measurements are made with a sound level meter it shall be an instrument in good operating condition meeting the requirements of a type i or type ii meter as specified by ansi standard 141983 or the latest approved revision thereof for purposes of this subsection a sound level meter shall contain at least an a and cweighted scale and both fast and slow meter response capability b if the measurements are made with other instruments the procedure shall be carried out in such a manner that the overall accuracy shall be at least that called for in ansi standard 141983 or the latest approved revision thereof for type ii instruments c when the location or distance prescribed in this subsection for measurement of sound is impractical or would provide misleading or inaccurate results measurements may be taken at other locations or distances using appropriate correction factors specified in this subsection or in other rules promulgated by the noise control office of the city d procedures and tests required by this subsection and not specified herein shall be placed on file with the city clerk 4 definitions the definitions of words and terms used in this subsection shall be the same as those set forth in these codified ordinances 5 noise disturbance prohibited no person shall make continue or cause to be made or continued except as permitted any noise or sound which constitutes a noise disturbance as defined in detective means a person who is hired for the purpose of conducting investigations involving a inquiries into unsolved crimes  b clandestine surveillance  c the search for missing persons  and d the search for lost or stolen property words in the singular shall include the plural and the plural shall include the singular  part 1994   exemptions a nothing in this chapter shall include the so engaged  or an insurance investigator  or a credit reporting bureau or agency whose business is principally the furnishing of information as to business and financial standing and credit or as a police officer with a state county or municipal police department or with an investigative agency of the united states of america or of any state county or municipality  or 2 has received a training or experience  part 1994   investigation and action on application a within sixty 60 days after receipt of an application as provided for in this chapter the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his or her proposed operation b after an examination of the application and such further inquiry and investigation as is deemed proper and necessary as to the good character competency and integrity of the applicant and the persons named in the application the local licensing authority shall as soon as practicable issue a license in a form prescribed by entertainment is to occur certification of such mailing and a list of the abutters is to be submitted to the city clerk prior to the councils consideration of the application upon receipt of an application for a new or an expanded class a or class b public entertainment license the city clerk shall also notify the police chief and fire chief who shall make such determinations and notify the city clerk accordingly if the application is denied by the council at the first hearing there shall be no second hearing  an affirmative vote of the council at the first hearing shall result in a second hearing at the next regularly scheduled council meeting b if a class a or class b public entertainment license is granted to the holder of a victualing license or alcoholicbeverage license the amplification shall cease at eleven pm sunday to thursday and at midnight on fridays saturdays and sundays before holidays c in all other instances where a class a or class b public entertainment provided in this chapter which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor or on his or her person while engaged in soliciting residence means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons contained within any type of building or structure solicitingmeans and includes any one or more of the following activities a seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods wares merchandise foodstuffs or services of any kind for any kind of consideration  b seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any kind  c seeking to obtain subscriptions to books magazines periodicals newspapers and every other kind of publication  or d seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association organization corporation or project 18   certificate of registration required every person desiring to engage in soliciting from persons in residences within the city is required to make written application for a certificate of registration as provided in such certificate shall be carried by the solicitor 19   application for certificate a application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the city the applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application as follows 1 the name and address of the present place of residence the period of residence at such address and the business address if other than the present address  2 the address of the place of residence during the past three years if other than the present address  3 the age of the applicant  4 a passport size photograph taken within six months of the date of the application  5 the name and address of the person whom or which the applicant is employed by or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation  6 the name and address of the employer during the past three years if other than the present employer  7 a description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage  8 the period of time for which the certificate is applied  9 the date or approximate date of the latest previous application for a certificate under this chapter if any  10 a statement as to whether or not a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked  11 a statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or the united states  12 the names of the magazines journals or books to be offered  13 the names of the three most recent communities where the applicant has solicited house to house  14 the proposed method of operation  15 the signature of the applicant  and 16 the social security number of the applicant b all statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath c the city clerk shall cause to be kept in his or her office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto including certificates of registration issued under this chapter and a record of the denial of applications applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed and every certificate issued and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued d no certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or the united states within five years of the date of the application nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter nor to any person whose certificate of registration issued under this chapter has previously been revoked as provided in e all applications shall be acted upon by the city within ten 10 days 20   revocation of certificate a any certificate of registration issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or has made a false material statement in the application or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under this chapter immediately upon such revocation written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified united states mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the application b immediately upon the giving of such notice the certificate of registration shall become null and void c the certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof 21   notice regulating soliciting every occupant of a residence who desires to secure the protection provided by the provisions of this chapter pertaining to soliciting shall give notice of his or her determination to invite or not to invite solicitors to his or her residence by exhibiting a weatherproof card approximately three inches by four inches in size upon or near the main entrance doors to the residence indicating the determination by the occupant and containing the applicable words as follows only solicitors registered in newport invited or no solicitors invited the letters shall be at least onethird inch in height for the purpose of uniformity the cards shall be provided by the chief of police to persons requesting the same at cost such cards so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon 22   duty of solicitors a every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the city upon which a residence is located shall first examine the notice provided for in if any is attached and be governed by the statement contained on any notice if the notice states only solicitors registered in newport invited then a solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration as provided in this chapter shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises and if the notice states no solicitors invited then the solicitor whether registered or not shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises b any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence whether invited or not shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant 23   uninvited soliciting prohibited no person shall go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with a violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance 24   time limit on soliciting no person whether registered under this chapter or such persons conduct any towing business for any department of the city they must comply with the following regulations a all cars towed must be stored in an area that is located no farther than two miles from the city of newport and is fenced or otherwise enclosed so as to be inaccessible to the general public or is within a building b vehicles ordered towed by the police division for a violation of any of the provisions of the traffic code must be picked up in the presence of an officer and the tow truck operator must give a receipt to the officer any visible damage to a vehicle should be noted on the receipt all tow companies must respond to a call within a reasonable period of time as determined by the chief of police c the operator of a motor vehicle found in violation of a parking law necessitating towing of such vehicle shall first be issued a violation citation prior to towing payable to the police division d all persons towing cars at the citys request must be fully insured and accept complete responsibility for damage to a towed vehicle or to the contents thereof while it is in their possession no towing company or employee thereof shall offer to pay any gratuity or thing of value to any city employee e cars shall be towed from private property where the city has no jurisdiction only at the request of the property owner  such private tows do not fall within the purview of this chapter except for violations of clearly marked fire lanes tow companies shall notify the police division of all private tows so as to prevent unnecessary reports of stolen cars and so that the owner can be informed as to the location of his or her car f no vehicle requested to be towed by the city shall be towed if the owner thereof appears before the vehicle is actually towed once a vehicle is hooked to a tow truck the owner thereof may reclaim the same before it reaches the impounding area by paying a fair percentage of a complete tow job the suggested percent is fifty 50 percent g no licensed person shall be eligible for city business unless he or she is current in payment of all city taxes and unless he or she or his or her authorized agent is in conformity with existing zoning ordinances with respect to his or her towing business within the city h all tow companies performing services for the city must notify the police division within sixty 60 minutes after the pickup of a car of the following 1 the registration number make model and color of the car  2 the location from where the vehicle was towed  and 3 the location where the vehicle is being held i all tow companies shall have an employee on duty on a twentyfour 24 hour basis so as to be able to return towed vehicles to the owner j all tow companies shall notify the police division once each week on monday by providing the division with a written list of all vehicles on their property or in their custody that are there as a result of a private or city tow whose owners they have not made contact with or who have not made contact with them this list shall be made out on a form provided by the division tow companies shall also notify the division of plans they have to dispose of unclaimed vehicles under of the general laws k all tow companies performing towing services whose principal place of business is not located in the city shall provide transportation to the owner of any vehicle which has been towed for a reasonable charge l all tow companies performing towing services in the city must register with the division of police and shall file a copy of their veterinarian d each carriage shall display its license along with its passenger capacity and schedule of rates  part 1994 prior code  87202   care of carriage horses a no horse shall be used to draw a carriage unless the animal is in good health as specified in c the newport animal control officer or in his absence a newport police officer may at any time order the licensee to have any horse examined by a veterinarian to determine the horses fitness for work if it should appear that the horse may be in any pain or distress physical or behavioral upon such a determination on the part of the city animal control officer the horse shall be removed from work and not returned to service until inspected by a licensed veterinarian who attests to the horses fitness to return to work b no horse younger than three years or older than twenty 20 years shall be licensed c no horse shall be subject to any cruel or harassing treatment by the licensee driver employees of the licensee or by any other person d the licensee shall provide to the city the name address and telephone number of a veterinarian to be contacted in an emergency e if stable facilities are utilized conditions shall be such that the horses health safety and comfort are met  part 1994 prior code  87203   working conditions a horses shall never be left unattended by the driver the driver shall maintain both hands on the reins when seated or in motion b horses used to pull carriages shall not be worked more than a total of six hours in a twentyfour 24 hour period including hours worked pursuant to any private contacts or for any other purpose c horses shall be given one day of rest after every three consecutive days worked  and ten 10 minutes of rest between each fare d potable water shall be made freely available to horses during rest periods watering shall meet work and weather requirements e each carriage shall be equipped with a device to catch manure a catcher shall not be affixed to nor hang from any part of the horses body and shall be emptied at a minimum after every second use f whips shall not be used g carriage horses shall not be worked at a speed faster than a slow trot when traffic permits they shall be walked h horses shall be driven on routes and during hours which minimize exposure to heavy traffic congestion as much as possible proposed routes and hours must be approved by the newport police department  part 1994 prior code  87204   weather conditions a owners and drivers shall not allow a horse to be worked during adverse weather conditions which shall include but not be restricted to snow or extreme cold heat or humidity b horses shall not be worked in temperatures that exceed eightynine 89 degrees fahrenheit or a combined temperature and humidity equal to one hundred forty 140 degrees or above  or a temperature of thirtytwo 32 degrees fahrenheit or below or a combined temperature and wind chill factor of thirtytwo 32 degrees fahrenheit or below c horses shall be curbed for work in areas protected from extremes of weather as seasonally appropriate including but not limited to shade during hot months protection from high winds and shall be blanketed during cold months  part 1994 prior code  87205   requirements for carriage drivers a drivers shall be a minimum of eighteen 18 years of age or older b each driver must possess a valid automobile drivers license c each driver shall not have been convicted within the past five years of driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or narcotics nor have had hisher license suspended or revoked for any other reason d no person who has ever been convicted of cruelty to animals shall be permitted to be employed by a carriage operator  part 1994 prior code  87206 pedicab the health safety and welfare of the public  2262014   definitions as used in this chapter applicant means an individual or a businesss authorized representative bicycle means any device upon which a headlight capable of projecting a beam of white light for a distance of three hundred 300 feet b it is unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated a pedicab during the hours of darkness without using batteryoperated taillights mounted on the right and left respectively at the same level on the rear exterior of the passenger compartment taillights shall be visible from all distances within five hundred 500 feet to the rear of the pedicab c pedicabs shall not operate between the hours of two am and six am d it is unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated a pedicab in an unsafe condition e no driver shall stop or offload passengers in any location which would disrupt the flow of traffic f the operation will not appear to be designed to defraud any person g there will be notices in each vehicle stating the charges and routes or methods of operation h no drivers shall park in any restricted zones identified for other vehicles i pedicab operators shall not park at any time in the recessed parking area on americas cup avenue south of long wharf designated for bus parking j pedicab operators shall not park at any time in the turn area on the south side of memorial boulevard west at thames street k pedicab operators offering tours at the humphrey j donnelly iii transportation and visitors center must register their vehicles in the visitors center and operate visitors center consolidated tour program l pedicabs shall be maintained in a business appearance acceptable to the public this includes a clean interior and exterior appearance m nothing shall be transported in a pedicab that will cause the interior of such cab to become soiled or offensive to passengers because of odor or appearance n smoking by operator or passengers in a pedicab is prohibited o all pedicab drivers must be dressed in a neat and professional manner p it shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab in or upon any street in the city unless such operator has a valid us drivers license and a pedicab operator permit q it shall be unlawful while the pedicab is in motion for the operator to collect fares make change or embark or debark passengers r it shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab upon a sidewalk s it shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab wearing headphones t it shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab more than one pedicab abreast except when overtaking and passing another pedicab proceeding in the same direction u it shall be unlawful for an operator to allow a passenger in the pedicab to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or to possess an open container of alcohol v it shall be unlawful for an operator to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or to possess an open container of alcohol while operating the pedicab w it shall be unlawful for an operator to refuse to provide a receipt in legible writing containing the name of the operator the decal number the total amount paid and the date of payment x pedicabs shall be operated in a manner as to be part of the normal traffic flow  provided however slower moving pedicabs shall safely pull temporarily to the side of streets and out of traffic flow so as to prevent unnecessary delays to following traffic  2262014   passenger seating requirements it is unlawful for any person to operate a pedicab while carrying a number of passengers that exceeds the number of available seats but in no case shall the number of passengers exceed three adult passengers  2262014   damage to public property it is unlawful for any person to operate a pedicab in a manner that results in damage to public property  2262014   fare schedule a pedicab operators shall post a fare schedule in a manner clearly visible to the public at all times while operating a pedicab b pedicab operators offering tours must have the fee schedule for such tours clearly visible to the public at all times c it is unlawful for any pedicab operator to demand from a passenger a fare or tour fee greater than that contained in the posted schedule d does not apply to fares for special tours provided that the fare for the special tour is agreed upon between the passenger and the pedicab operator prior to the title 6  animals general provisions   titleintent and purpose a this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the newport animal control  b it is the intent and purpose of council that this chapter and any amendments and additions hereto will protect animals from neglect injury abuse and inhumane treatment  assist in providing and ensuring proper care treatment and shelter for animals and when necessary proper and humane destruction or disposal of the same  and at the same time protect the health welfare and safety of the public generally 01   definitions words in this chapter shall be construed according to their common use and definitions and not as socalled words of art whenever possible and practical specifically as used in this chapter animal means any vertebrate member of the animal kingdom other than man animal control officer or control officer means a person employed and so designed by the city for the enforcement of this chapter and related ordinances and where appropriate statutes of the state and generally any member of the police division animal shelter means any premises now or hereafter designated by the city for the impoundment confinement care and shelter of any animal in the enforcement of this chapter such term shall be construed as being synonymous with pound at large means any animal when it is free in or on any public street sidewalk way beach park grounds or building without or beyond the physical restraint or control of its owner bite means the actual puncture or tearing of the skin inflicted by the teeth of any animal collared refers to a dog that is wearing a collar around its neck if such a dog is on or in a public street sidewalk way beach park grounds or building such collar shall bear a plate or tag whereon the name and address of its owner is displayed and when appropriate a license tag as prescribed herein director means the director of public safety or his or her authorized delegate designee or agent in heat means sexual excitement in a female animal and such periods of time when animals are particularly attractive to male animals of the same species leashed means restrained by a cord chain or similar device not in excess of eight feet in length attached to an animals collar and held or led by a person capable of maintaining control of such an animal licensed refers to a dog or other animal when appropriate required by licensed by any ordinance of the city or statute of the state that has lawfully attached or affixed to its collar a tag or identifying device issued pursuant to law owner means any person who owns keeps harbors has custody and control of or who otherwise physically possesses and controls an animal owner does not include an animal control officer police officer or director keeper manager or employee of a shelter or pound spayed female means any female animal that has been surgically rendered incapable of conception vicious means an animal that is dangerously aggressive savage ferocious or depraved in its attitudes toward other animals or to persons to the extent that it injures or is likely to injure or cause injury to such animals or persons or an animal that has a propensity to want to attack or attempt to attack other animals or persons an animal shall not be deemed vicious if it is provoked or if it bites attacks or attempts to attack any other animal or a person in selfdefense or in defense of its owner or its owners property an animal shall not be deemed vicious merely by reason of growling or barking 02   enforcementrules and regulations a the director of public safety shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter the director may designate the chief of police members of the police division and the animal control officer and his agents to effectuate such enforcement and to issue citations which may be paid by mail to the owners of dogs for violations of any animal control ordinance b rules and regulations issued or approved by the director shall be promulgated from time to time to implement enforcement of this chapter copies of such rules and regulations shall be published and made available to the public at the police division and at the office of the city clerk 03   animal control officer a upon recommendation of the chief of police the director of public safety shall designate one or more animal control officers who shall be charged with specific enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and any related ordinances or statutes except as may be otherwise provided by law b in the event of a vacancy in the office of the control officer or his or her absence or unavailability any member of the police division shall exercise his or her duties c the control officer shall wear a uniform approved by the director and a numbered badge designed to identify him or her as such officer which badge shall be the property of the city and which badge shall be surrendered by the officer upon his or her termination of employment or separation or suspension from office 04   complaints and investigations a a complaint of an alleged violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be made to the police division to which the complainant shall furnish his or her name address and telephone number if any and the details of the alleged offense every such complaint shall be verified by the animal control officer by confirming the alleged violation himself or herself or by one or more persons having separate residences or regularly employed in the neighborhood b upon receipt of such a complaint if it appears that a violation of the law does probably exist the control officer shall investigate the same and when necessary seize and impound any animal about which the complaint is made such seizure and impoundment may be made only in the event of an emergency such as when the animal presents a threat to itself when it is injured and its owner fails or refuses to make provision for the confinement or treatment of such animal or when such animal presents an immediate threat to public health safety or welfare in any degree in all other instances if the complaint is found to be justified the control officer shall take such appropriate action as is prescribed by this chapter c the control officer shall forthwith submit to the chief of police a report of his or her investigation if it is determined by the chief or by the director of public safety that prosecutive action for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or any related ordinance or statute is warranted as a result of such report he or she shall direct that such action be initiated d when a complaint is made in writing to the chief of police or the control officer by one or more persons who reside or are employed in an area frequented by an animal about which a complaint is made which complaint is that such animal is vicious exhibits a propensity for viciousness is destructive of their property or the property of others is regularly permitted to roam free upon public highways and sidewalks or upon their property or creates a disturbance by regular prolonged and persistent barking or howling then upon verification of such complaint by the control officer the officer shall direct the owner of such animal to forthwith restrain confine or in cases of such barking or howling muzzle such animal if such owner refuses or neglects to comply with such direction the control officer shall seize and impound the animal e if a further complaint is made about such animal the officer may issue to the owner a citation for a violation hereof in a manner and sum as hereinafter provided in f and  or where deemed appropriate may take prosecutive action against the owner f any person claiming to have been bitten by an animal must submit to the control officer or the chief of police satisfactory evidence that such person did in fact suffer a bite and that an identified animal did probably effect such bite 05   reports of bites poisonings and wounds a every person who treats any person for bite injuries including bite injuries sustained by an owner caused by any animal shall report the same to the control officer which report shall contain the name and address of the person treated and the circumstances under which the injuries were sustained b every person who treats any animal for poisoning or gunshot or arrow wounds shall similarly report the same to the control officer 13   rabies a every licensed veterinarian shall report to the control officer any animal known or suspected by him or her to be rabid or to have been exposed to rabies in any manner b all licensed physicians or practitioners of medical science including nurses shall report to the control officer any person treated by them for rabies or the prevention thereof the name and address of the person so treated and the manner in which such person was exposed to such disease c the owner of any dog over the age of six months shall have such dog vaccinated against rabies which vaccination shall provide immunization against such disease for not less than twelve 12 months such vaccination shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of a license for such dog and such owner shall present proof of the same upon request by the city clerk the control officer or any police officer of the city d any person who has custody or control of an animal that has bitten a person shall immediately notify the control officer if the animal shows signs of illness unusual behavior or escapes the confinement required by b if the animal dies while in such confinement the person in possession thereof shall immediately notify the control officer of such fact and when required by law shall immediately surrender the body of such animal to the state department of health 14   animal shelter and control vehicles a the city shall either establish an animal shelter for the impoundment and maintenance of animals seized or impounded under the provisions of this chapter or otherwise according to law or avail itself of the use of a nonprofit animal shelter designated by it and authorized to operated as such shelter under law b the shelter so established or designated shall be available for the use of the control officer at any time and shall be available to the public during regular hours established by the keeper or manager of the same c no person shall break into or open any pound or shelter wherein animals are impounded or any vehicle used by the control officer for the impoundment confinement or transportation of animals and no person shall in any way unlawfully remove or release any animal from such pound shelter or vehicle 15   recordscontrol officers duties a the control officer shall daily compile in duplicate a list of animals seized and impounded which list shall be kept at the police division and at the shelter and which list shall be available for public examination on request b the control officer shall maintain for two years a record of all citations issued pursuant to this chapter during the period of july 1st th of any year which record shall set forth in detail the descriptions of all animals which were subject to the citations the reasons such citations were issued the date of issuance thereof the names and addresses of the persons cited and the disposition of all fees received in relation thereto c the control officer shall also maintain a record for a like period of two years of all animals seized and impounded within such period of july 1st th setting forth detailed descriptions of such animals dates of seizure and impoundment and reasons therefor dates and manner of disposal of such animals and disposition of all moneys received in relation thereto d the shelter shall maintain a record similar to that hereinbefore described but including the dates of spaying or neutering of such animals 16   dogs aiding handicapped personsinterference with control officer a unless otherwise provided by law no person owning operating or maintaining any place of business to which the public is invited or any means of public conveyance shall exclude therefrom any dog trained to assist blind or handicapped persons when such dogs are actually being used for that purpose b no person shall interfere with hinder or obstruct the control officer in the performance of his or her duties or attempt to release any animal from his or her custody except as may be authorized in this chapter 17 animal control regulations
